protocol.title: Potency Test: Glucose Stimulated Insulin Release Assay
protocol.title_html: Potency Test: Glucose Stimulated Insulin Release Assay

source.description:
Culture media that is to be used for overnight culturing is prepared as described below.
  • The Prodo Labs PIM(R) should be stored between 2° and 8°C upon receipt.
  • The (heat inactivated) Gemini AB serum and the PIM(G) vials should be stored at -5° to -20°C.
The Ciprofloxacin powder can be stored on the shelf but filter sterilized suspension aliquots should be stored at -5° to -20°C.

source.body: Record preparation on Attachment 1: Solutions Preparation Sheet, of this SOP.

source.description:
Prepare 1 bottle of PIM(R) media prior to the collection by adding the following:
  • Thaw and add 5 mL of PIM(G).
  • Add 25 mL of AB serum (5%v/v).
  • Add 0.5 mL of prepared sterile ciprofloxacin aliquot.
  • Once all additives have been added to the bottle of PIM(R), it is now referred to as PIM(R) complete.

source.body: Note: If a prepared media bottle is to be used from a previous isolation, it must have been filter sterilized at the end of the previous use. The media will expire within 30 days, once it has been fully supplemented.
Record preparation on Attachment 1: Solutions Preparation Sheet, of this SOP.

source.description:
On the day of islet shipment, remove at least 400 IEQ (calculate using islet count per volume) from the purest layer using sterile technique.
The formula will be:
Total IEQ/(Total mL * 1000 μL)= x IEQ/μL
then
400 IEQ/x IEQ/μL = y μL

Place islets in a 100 mm Petri dish, add
, label, and cover.
Place the dish in a 37°C, 5 % CO2 incubator.

Culture islets for
–
.

source.body: NOTE: If 100 % of the 400 IEQ are cultured and there is overnight loss, there are 80 IEQ/300 μl in this suspension of islets. There will be a loss of islets during the culture, so the recommended target of 50 – 75 IEQ per well is likely to be achieved. (A 300 μl aliquot containing ~80 IEQ will be added to each insert in the next step). 400 IEQ ÷ 1500 μl (100 μl islets in PIM(R) Complete Media + 1400 μl PIM(R) Complete media) = 0.26 IEQ/ μl 0.26 IEQ/μl X 300 μl = 79.9 IEQ per well (with no islet loss).

source.description: Place an insert in each of the empty wells D1, D2, D3.

Slowly pipette
of well-mixed islet suspension into each insert in row D.
Place insert on sterile gauze to drain liquid out completely. Transfer insert with islets to the wells A1, A2, A3.

Replace the lid on the plate and incubate for
at
in 5 % CO2.

source.title: Glucose Stimulation: Low Glucose Stimulation (Row B)

source.description: Remove plate from incubator.

source.title: Glucose Stimulation: Low Glucose Stimulation (Row B)

source.description: Transfer the inserts from row A to corresponding wells in row B (B1, B2, B3) as described below:

source.body: Row A allows islets to equilibrate from the culture media to Krebs basal media. Samples from these wells in Row A are discarded at the end of the procedure.

source.title: Glucose Stimulation: Low Glucose Stimulation (Row B)

source.description: Slowly and gently, lift the insert up from its corresponding well, using forceps.

source.body: NOTE: Bumping insert will cause the islets to release insulin resulting in false stimulation results.

source.title: Glucose Stimulation: Low Glucose Stimulation (Row B)

source.description: Allow liquid to drain from each insert back into the well by “wicking” the liquid from the mesh bottom of the insert against the side of the well.

source.title: Glucose Stimulation: Low Glucose Stimulation (Row B)

source.description: When the insert looks well-drained, gently blot the bottom of the insert on sterile gauze before gently setting the insert in the corresponding well in row B.

source.title: Glucose Stimulation: Low Glucose Stimulation (Row B)

source.description: Repeat the above steps from 38.1-38.3 for all inserts from row A to row B.

source.title: Glucose Stimulation: Low Glucose Stimulation (Row B)

source.description: Take Zero Time media samples for Low Glucose media from wells B1, B2, B3:

source.title: Glucose Stimulation: Low Glucose Stimulation (Row B)

source.description: Allow the level of liquid to equilibrate between inside and outside of each insert (now in its corresponding well).

source.title: Glucose Stimulation: Low Glucose Stimulation (Row B)

source.description: Lift each insert and drain the liquid back into its corresponding well. Do not blot the insert on sterile gauze.

source.description:
Remove
of media from each well (from the well, not the insert). Transfer media to corresponding microcentrifuge tubes labeled “Zero time – Low Glucose”, B1, B2, or B3, Lot#, Date, Tech.

source.description: As soon as the sample is collected, immediately replace the insert in its corresponding well. Repeat this for each of the inserts in row B.

source.title: Glucose Stimulation: Low Glucose Stimulation (Row B)

at

source.description: After 1 hour, carefully remove the plate from incubator.

source.title: Glucose Stimulation: Low Glucose Stimulation (Row B)

source.description:
Remove inserts from row B wells and transfer each into the corresponding well in row C as described above.
Collect all media from each well in row B to corresponding microcentrifuge tubes labeled “Low Glucose”, B1, B2, or B3 and store at
–
until assay completion.

source.title: Glucose Stimulation: Low Glucose Stimulation (Row B)

source.description: Take Zero Time media samples for High Glucose media as described in steps 39.1 through 39.4 above but transfer media to tubes labeled “Zero time - High Glucose”.

source.title: Glucose Stimulation: High Glucose Stimulation (Row C)

Replace lid on plate and incubate for
at
in 5 % CO2.

source.title: Glucose Stimulation: High Glucose Stimulation (Row C)

source.description: Remove inserts from row C wells and transfer each into the corresponding well in row D as described above. Collect all media from each well in row C to corresponding microcentrifuge tubes labeled “High Glucose”, C1, C2, or C3.

According to Mercodia (kit manufacturer), samples stored at 4 – 8ºC must be assayed within 24 hours, while samples stored at stable -20ºC can be assayed within 3 months. Place all samples in appropriate storage.

source.body: Note, if RIA is the assay to be used for insulin determination, store as the RIA protocol recommends.

source.description: Assay insulin samples using an ELISA assay kit (such as Mercodia) within 10 days of broadcast.

source.body: If RIA is the assay to be used for insulin determination, results should be available and entered into the database within 10 days of broadcast.

source.description:
Results should be reported on the website under Potency Assay as Stimulation Index (SI);
Stimulation\; Index (SI) = \left( \frac{Insulin\; concentration\; after\; high\; glucose\; concentration\; stimulation}{Insulin\; concentration\; after\; low\; glucose\; concentration\; stimulation} \right)
Results from each of three samples are averaged and reported within 10 days of broadcast.

source.title: Preparation of Human Insulin ELISA Solutions

source.description:
Human Insulin ELISA Kit
The following reagents come in the Human Insulin ELISA kit, ready for use:
  • Insulin Standards (S0-S5)
  • Microplate strips coated with murine anti-insulin
  • Substrate TMB Colorless Solution (light sensitive)
  • Stop Solution
  • Microplate strips coated with murine anti-insulin
  • Substrate TMB Colorless Solution (light sensitive)
  • Stop Solution

source.body: Note: It is not required to use the ELISA for measuring insulin content of media. If using an RIA however, standards should be established and dilutions should be made in accordance with the assay’s recommendations.

source.title: Preparation of Human Insulin ELISA Solutions: Preparation of Controls

source.description: Establishment of acceptable ranges for a new lot of controls using manufacturer’s procedures.

Supernatants collected from the glucose challenge wells are diluted using DPBS for the ELISA. The commonly used dilution factors are 1:50 and 1:100. To select an optimal dilution factor, the insulin concentration detected by ELISA should be in the range of 31.8 to 191 mU/l.

Bring all reagents and samples to
.

source.body: See Attachment 3: Glucose Stimulated Insulin Release Worksheet

Read optical density at 450 nm using bi-chromatic measurement with reference at 600 – 690 nm within

Record the data on Attachment 3: Glucose Stimulated Insulin Release Worksheet, of this SOP, and perform calculations required.

source.title: Quality Control, Interpretation and Release Criteria

source.description:
For assay acceptance:
  • All control values must be within their 2 SD established ranges
  • Standard values must be within ± 15 % of their nominal values
  • Triplicates of standards, controls and samples must have Coefficients of Variation (CV) ≤ 20 %

source.body: For an unacceptable assay: If the assay is unacceptable for any of these reasons, sample values may not be reported. The assay should be investigated and repeated.

materials.name: Mercodia Human Insulin ELISA or equivalent

description:
The goal of the Integrated Islet Distribution Program (IIDP) is to develop a uniform standardized shipping method among all the subcontracted IIDP centers that will result in minimal loss of quality or quantity of shipped islets (as compared to control islets remaining at the IIDP center). The objective of this Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) is to be a model for site-specific SOPs that define the method for quantitative determination of insulin released after glucose stimulation for proving the potency of the human islet preparation shipped by the IIDP.
GSIR Overview:
After overnight culture at 37°C (12 – 24 hrs), human islets are incubated with media containing a relatively low
concentration of glucose (2.8 mM) and a sample of the supernatant is taken. Then the same islets are incubated
with media containing a higher glucose concentration (28 mM) and a sample of the supernatant is taken. The
amount of insulin present in both the supernatant samples is measured using a commercially available Human
Insulin ELISA kit. The stimulation index is calculated by dividing insulin concentration of the supernatant
from the 28 mM glucose incubation by the insulin concentration of the supernatant from the 2.8 mM glucose
incubation.
Reference:
Purified Human Pancreatic Islets, Glucose Stimulated Insulin Release Determination by ELISA; DAIT, NIAID, NIH SOP Appendix, Document No. 3104, A03, Revision Number 03; Effective Date: 25 Oct 2010; Supersedes Date: 08 June 2010.
